entry.title: The Home Page DLC
entry.content:
Welcome to my first blog post to this website of mine. I will be building on the information present in the home page, so I suggest you read it. Think of it this way, if my home page is the intro, this is the full documentary to know everything you need to about me.

Being Queer

I feel placing myself into a box as if I perfectly fit into it is lying. So I don't use labels quite as "labels", more like descriptors (but that's a discussion for another post).

With that said, I would describe myself as a transgender individual who uses she/they pronouns. As for my sexual and romantic attraction, I don't really mind gender, sex or amount of partners. Whether I have a preference or not and what it is depends on when you ask.

Schooling

I am currently going into my last year of high school, yippee! Over the last 3 years, I've taken every computer related class I could get. In fact, I have taken almost every class the school district has to offer and I could get a certificate of proficiency if I pass the final class in the series this year. Other than that class, I only need to finish off my English class credit to graduate. With all the spare class slots I have, I plan to be a teacher assistant for the only computer science teacher in the school.

After high school, I want to go to the nearby university and get a degree in computer science. I will probably just get my bachelor's degree, but if things work in my favor, I might even pursue my master's.

Programming Experience

The summer before 7th grade (about 5 years ago), I asked myself and the internet "how do you make a Discord bot?". After some searching, I found CodeLyon's Channel and was introduced to programming, more specifically NodeJS. At the time, I was DEEP into tutorial hell, but over time I learned to experiment, not just copy & paste code from videos. I stuck with NodeJS till my 10th grade year, when I took Intro to Computer Science and Game Development where I did some light web development and played some with Unity.

It wasn't till last year (11th grade) that I started taking programming seriously and considered it as a career option. This is when I took Advanced Computer Programming, and it was boring as hell. The series of computer science courses offered at my high school are pretty copy and paste, and it shows. Anyhow, I was taught Python formally in this class and got a chance to tamper with Java for my final project (my teacher saw potential and gave me a harder final). This year, I will be taking a class going over DSA in C++. Then, with that under my belt, I want to try and learn Rust and all the low level programming philosophies.

I forgot web development.

Those skills are mostly self taught other than some good design and industry practices from my Intro to Web Development class.

Last Words

I hope you found at least some part of this post interesting. As for my next post, I don't have a good topic yet, other than my monthly post (scheduled for early September). If you want to submit a topic idea, DM me on Discord at monicode.dev or email me at monika@monicode.dev. Have a good one, and thanks for reading!

entry.title: September's Monthly Post
entry.content:
Welcome to my monthly post for September! This is my status update post where I talk about where I've been, what I've done, and/or what I've learned in the last month. So lets get into it with my biggest news...

Getting my license!

I officially got my license and my car registered! About two weeks ago I got my plates for my car and about a week ago I got the actual card for my license. However, there is still some work to be done. You see, I got an old 2001 Saturn L200 (a.k.a. LS1) that has driven over 200,000 miles over it's life time. Owning that old and that used of a car requires some maintenance. As you can see below, it's not the best cosmetically: sun damaged paint, no hood emblem (the new one just came in the mail), cracked windshield, no hub caps, etc.

Mechanically, it has a 4-cylinder 2.2 L engine (translation: small engine and no get-up-and-go). It currently has no AC and some regular maintenance here and there is a little over due. However, I'm not going in completely blind. My mother used to work on her old '99 Jeep and my father still maintains his car. Adding on, I'm also taking my school's Intro to Automotive class next semester. With all that said, I'd say I did really good with my first car. I'm hoping to learn a lot from owning an older car that requires a little bit of love and care. On the topic of learning...

School has started for me

Unfortunately, I now have to go to school (hence why this post is being posted later than I wanted). Luckily, I don't have much this first semester. My school operates on an A/B day schedule. My A days are pretty boring, only teacher assistant work and study hall. But my B days are where all the fun is. I have a class on Network Fundamentals and Computer Systems. Unfortunately, I don't get to do DSA till next semester :(

Misc

As for miscellaneous news, I am trying Arch Linux again, this time on my Thinkpad T495. I got inspired by my friend, ztchary, to work on a rice setup. Once I've made some good progress or I finish it, there may be an update post on it if I don't decide to wait till the next monthly post. Lastly, I got promoted at my job to be shift lead! It also comes with a nice $2.35 pay bump, but also, more responsibilities (more explanation to the lateness of this post).

Last Words

Thanks for reading to the end! Like always, I hope you found some of this interesting. As said before, I plan on making an update post to the Arch Linux rice. If I don't before the beginning of October, then I'll see you for the next monthly post! I love y'all and have a good one!
